Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Investigating the Use of Graphene and Other 2D Materials for Use in Infrared Photodetectors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Infrared (IR) sensors operate by absorbing incoming IR radiation and transforming that energy into heat. This heat from the absorber is then diffused through a thermoelectric material that converts the heat into electricity. The electrical signal can then be used to determine the energy of the incoming IR radiation. However, losses occurring at the junction between the absorber and the thermoelectric material cause a reduction in sensitivity and response speed which degrades performance. By using graphene or other two dimensional (2D) materials, the junction can be eliminated. This is because, despite their lack of thickness, these materials have good absorption properties and can also transform heat into electricity, making them excellent candidates for improved IR sensors. Understanding of the parameters that maximize both the absorption and the thermoelectric conversion will be essential in creating better sensors. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Professor Seong Chu Lim, a noted expert on 2D nanomaterials, at Sungkyunkwan University (SKKU) in Suwon, South Korea.

Thermoelectric materials such as ZnO and SbTe are widely used in thermal applications but are transparent to incoming IR radiation due to a large band gap energy. Graphene however is a good IR absorber. However, thermoelectric IR sensors based on graphene or other 2D materials will require investigation of the parameters that influence the thermoelectric effect and the IR responsivity. To accomplish this, the researcher will focus on improving the understanding of the underlying physical phenomena so that systematic improvements of the sensor can be realized. The design of the sensor must consider both device physics and structural parameters of the sensor. If a structure can be implemented that transduces the photothermoelectric effect into an electrical output, the detection of light over a wide optical range with a constant efficiency using graphene as the absorbing material is possible.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the EAPSI program was to further the understanding of the thermoelectric properties of graphene and other 2-dimensional (2D) materials as well as to increase understanding of foreign cultures and opportunities for international collaboration.

The goals were acheived by working in collaboration with Korean researchers at Sungkyunkwan University (SKKU) in South Korea. There I was able to work in the Center for Integrated Nanostructure Physics under Dr. Seongchu Lim along with his graduate students. While at SKKU, research proceeded on the understanding of thermoelectric characteristics of graphene.

In order to perform the research, I was able to learn about controlling low temperature equipment capable of reaching temperatures just a few degrees above absolute zero. Additionally, I was able to learn advanced measurement techniques that could provide the high resolutions needed in order to measure the thermoelectric characteristics desired. This further allowed me to return this information back to my lab and update our own testing setup in order to continue the research at my home institution.

Thermoelectric testing continues at the University of Pittsburgh on both graphene and other 2D materials such as MoS2 and MoTe2. This will allow us to move on to creating IR sensors that are potentially cheaper, more efficient, and better for the environment than current technology allows. Additionally, these thermoelectric properties could be used to create other devices such as a thermoelectric generator which could, for example, use body heat to replenish a cell phone battery.

Research was not the only goal of the program and the 2 months spent in Korea allowed for an increased cultural understanding on both a professional and social setting. The working hours in Korea are much longer than in the US, however the students would take breaks for both food and enjoyment such as playing soccer or "Jokgu" which is a combination of soccer and volleyball that I found very enjoyable.

On a more social level I was able to gain an appreciation for Korean cuisine as well as the vibrant city life present in Seoul. I was also able to learn about Korea's rich history by visiting some of its historical locations, including a Buddhist temple and a Korean palace. Additionally, I was lucky enough to learn about some of South Korea's traditional clothing and martial arts practices.

The EAPSI program has been a great success, allowing increased research collaboration between SKKU and the University of Pittsburgh to the point that a graduate student from SKKU was able to travel to the University of Pittsburgh to learn from us as well as increasing cultural understanding of South Korea.
